II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

The causes of poverty and marginalization of rural women are multiple, interrelated, and 
2. 
deep-rooted.  Lessons  from  past  programs,  which  aimed  at  empowering  women  in  Nepal  and 
reducing  their  poverty  (Appendix  2),  show  that  no  single-focus  approach  can  be  effective. 
Instead, a holistic, phased, process-oriented approach is needed to systematically improve the 
well-being of Nepal's poorest and most disadvantaged rural women.  
 
A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

While  per  capita  income  grew  at  2.7%  during  the  1990s,  the  incidence  of  poverty  in 
3. 
Nepal  remains  high.  Poverty  is  more  severe  in  rural  areas–where  88%  of  the  population  live–
than  in  urban  areas  and  affects  most  households.2  Nepal  has  made  considerable  strides  in 
improving  education,  health,  and  other  social  services  during  the  last  decade,  but  the  level  of 
human  development  remains  among  the  lowest  in  the  world  and  below  that  of  most  other 
countries  in  South  Asia.3  Women,  constrained  by  natural  and  social  barriers,  bear  a 
disproportionate share of the poverty burden as shown by a gender-related development index 
of 119 out of 144 countries. Women have unequal access to food, education, and health care, 
and  suffer  from  long  working  hours  and  high  levels  of  social  exclusion  from  productive 
resources  and  community  activities.4  This  type  of  discrimination  against  women  and  girls  is 
more severe in the terai and Midwestern and Far Western regions and creates a fertile ground 
for trafficking (Supplementary Appendix A) and child labor, which are reportedly increasing.  
 
4. 
Poverty is exacerbated by caste- and ethnicity-based discrimination. Nepalese society is 
characterized  by  complex  differences  in  ethnicity,  caste,  language,  and  religion  and  the  caste 
system  defines  access  to  resources  and  opportunities.  At  each  level  in  the  caste  system  or 
within an ethnic group, women are more disadvantaged than men. It is estimated that the entire 
population  of  dalit5  women  live  below  the  official  poverty  line.  Literacy  rate  is  on  average  7% 
among dalit women and life expectancy is 10–14 years lower than that for high caste women. 
 
Gender-based  vulnerability  has  been  intensified  by  the  ongoing  conflict  between  the 
5. 
Government and the insurgents. Because rural economic activity has been curtailed, many men 
have left to seek work elsewhere on a long-term basis, leaving women responsible for meeting

Rural women suffer from lack of opportunities to earn income outside their households; 
6. 
this lack further weakens their already low status. The strong gender division of labor requires 
that  women  undertake  almost  all  domestic  duties,  including  time-consuming  tasks  of  firewood 
and water collection. Women spend an average of 11 hours a week more than men on work for 
the household and girls from an early age are expected to assist their mothers in the household 
tasks. This chore prevents women from engaging in productive activities and from migrating to 
seek higher-return employment, and girls from attending school. Furthermore, women and girls 
put in more hours in agricultural production than men and boys.6 Women are generally engaged 
in semi-skilled and unskilled jobs closely related to their household tasks or local jobs. For the 
same  work,  they  earn  about  70%  of  men’s  wages  (Supplementary  Appendix  C).  Their 
participation  in  activities  with  higher  return  is  limited  by  (i)  lack  of  time,  (ii)  lack  of  access  to 
economic  assets7  and  to  marketing  networks  and  technology,  (iii)  restricted  mobility  and  risk-
taking capacity, (iv) low education and lack of vocational training, and (v) social discrimination 
on  the  part  of  the  employers.  The  concentration  of  women  in  nonpaying  or  low-skilled 
employment  means  that  more  than  half  of  the  population  makes  a  fraction  of  its  potential 
contribution to economic development at the household, community, and national levels.  
 
7. 
Women  in  Nepal  have  limited  legal  rights.  Although  the  1990  Constitution  guarantees 
equal  treatment  and  some  discriminatory  provisions  were  recently  modified  through  the  11th 
amendment  to  the  Muluki  Ain  (Country  Code),  substantial  discrimination  continues  to  exist  in 
areas such as citizenship and related rights, property rights, and inheritance. In addition, there is 
limited knowledge and awareness of relevant legislation, and legal institutions do not offer easy 
redress to women wanting to assert their rights. Partly because of this situation but also due to 
social  patterns  of  behavior  and  gender  insensitive  attitudes,  the  application  of  relevant 
legislation and the enforcement of women’s rights are limited. 
 
8. 
In both the household and the public arena, women are also vulnerable to gender-based 
violence,  such  as  verbal  and  sexual  harassment,  rape,  and  trafficking.  An  estimated  95%  of 
women and girls have firsthand knowledge of violence, 77% of which was from their own family 
members.8 The costs of gender-based violence to the potential for socioeconomic development 
can  be  counted  not  only  in  impacts  on  health  and  eroded  self-confidence,  but  also  in  loss  of 
productive  potential.  The  deteriorating  security  situation  and  insurgency  have  also  presented

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

10.  Multiple  Forms  of  Discrimination.  The  low  status  of  rural  women  in  Nepal  can  be 
traced to economic, legal, cultural, political, and institutional constraints, which are interrelated 
and mutually reinforcing. The analysis of rural women’s problems suggests a need for a holistic 
approach  and  targeted  interventions  in  four  synergistic  areas:  (i)  economic,  to  enhance  rural 
women’s skills and access to productive assets, both for self- and wage employment; (ii) legal, 
to improve legal awareness of women's rights, access to legal services and alternative dispute 
resolution  mechanisms,  and  gender  responsiveness  of  judicial  and  administrative  institutions; 
(iii)  social,  to  reduce  women’s  time  burdens  through  improved  household  technology  and 
gender-sensitive  community  infrastructure,  and  to  promote  social  mobilization  for  collective 
action;  and  (iv)  institutional  strengthening,  to  build  the  capacity  of  Government  agencies  and 
women’s  representatives  to  promote  gender  equality  (GE).  The  project  has  been  designed  to 
further these interrelated objectives in a coordinated and sustainable manner. 
 
11. 
Drivers for  Change. Centuries-old cultural and behavioral norms must be overcome if 
disadvantaged,  low-caste,  and  ethnic  women  are  to  make  their  full  contributions  to  Nepal's 
socioeconomic  development.  It  would  be  immodest  to  suggest  that  any  single  project  can 
achieve  this  outcome.  Ultimately,  empowerment  will  be  driven  by  the  realization  among  all  of 
Nepal's  people,  including  men,  that  (i)  women  and  disadvantaged  groups  can  and  will  make 
much  greater  contributions  to  the  socioeconomic  uplift  of  households,  communities,  and  the 
nation;  (ii)  all  household  and  community  members  will  benefit  from  this;  (iii)  legal  and  social 
sanctions  can  and  will  be  applied  effectively  to  protect  the  rights  of  women  and  the 
disadvantaged; and, therefore, (iv) it is in the self-interest of all to support or at least accept the 
process  of  empowerment  of  women  (EOW).  The  Project  will  provide  appropriate  economic, 
legal,  social  and  institutional  incentives  to  initiate  this  process  of  change  and  institutions,  e.g., 
the  National  Women’s  Commission  (NWC)  and  the  Gender  Stakeholders  Group  (GSG),  will 
facilitate and motivate these changes beyond the Project’s implementation.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Objective  

15. 
The goal of the Project is to reduce poverty in the project area by empowering poor rural 
women  and  members  of  other  disadvantaged  groups,  such  as  ethnic and  low-caste  women.16 
The  objective  is  to  improve  the  socioeconomic  conditions  of  poor  rural  women  through  a 
process  of  economic,  social,  legal,  and  political  empowerment  by  (i)  strengthening  their 
individual  capabilities  to  improve  their  access  to  and  control  over  assets,  (ii)  building  group 
support for individual and collective action to influence and hold institutions accountable, and (iii) 
reforming  Government  institutions  and  processes  to  become  gender-responsive  and  include 
previously marginalized women in development opportunities. 
 
The project area (map) covers two clusters for a total of 15 districts: 8 in the Midwestern

These  districts  represent  the  poorest  and  most  disadvantaged  areas  of  Nepal,  where  gender

support  to  women’s  savings  and  credit  groups  formed  under  the  MCPW  in  12  districts  and  5 
towns in the Midwestern, Central, and Eastern regions.18

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Expected Benefits and Impacts 

62. 
The  Project  will  cover  some  of  the  poorest  and  most  remote  communities  and 
households in 80 VDCs (30 in the terai and 50 in the hills and mountains) in 15 core districts. 
The  project  activities  are  expected  to  target  poor  rural  women,  including  low-caste  and  ethnic 
groups,  and  to  reach  30,000  women  in  the  ME  program,  100,000  people  through  the  legal 
component, 12,600 women and their households in the community-based water supply, 16,800 
in the sanitation schemes, 38,500 for time-saving household devices, and 9,200 in rehabilitation 
of local trails and bridges. At least 30% of women will be from dalits and ethnic groups.38 The 
actual  number  of  beneficiaries  will  be  considerably  less  than  the  sum  of  207,100  as  some 
women  will  participate  in  more  than  one  scheme.  Given  the  demand-driven  approach  for 
selecting  the  subprojects,  quantification  of  economic  benefits  involves  strong  assumptions  on 
the proportion of funds used for the different activities; therefore a full benefit- cost analysis of 
the  overall  project  was  considered  impractical  (Appendix  13).  Appendix  14  is  the  summary 
poverty reduction and social strategy. 
 
63. 
The  economic  empowerment  component  will  provide  services  and  training  to  30,000 
women, half of whom are envisaged to undertake ME on a continuous basis. About 60% of the 
MEs  are  assumed  to  be  from  the  terai  and  most  are  expected  to  be  agriculture-based.  The 
annual  income  generation  is  estimated  at  NRs2,900  per  annum  for  small-scale  commercial 
vegetable production to NRs110,000 per annum for operating a tea shop. The estimated returns 
from MEs are substantial and will have a significant effect on the well-being of the families as 
well  as  the  communities.  The  immediate  beneficiaries  will  be  women  who  have  the  ability  to 
take risks and their success is expected to have a demonstration effect, thus encouraging other 
poor women to establish MEs. 
 
64. 
The legal empowerment component will indirectly support the registration for citizenship 
and  identity  cards,  which  are  requirements  for  education,  job,  and  credit  applications.  The 
legislative  changes  and  their  enhanced  enforcement  will  (i)  put  in  place  property  rights  for 
women;l  (ii)  increase  women's  access  to  and  control  over  assets;  and  (iii)  increase  protection 
from  rape,  domestic  violence,  and  crime.  These  changes  will  translate  into  increased  income-
earning capacity for women and their integration into the mainstream of society in the long term. 
 
65. 
In the social empowerment component, the education programs will impact positively on 
(i)  women’s  personal  development,  self-esteem,  and  awareness;  (ii)  women’s  participation  in 
community  activities;  (iii)  local  economies;  and  (iv)  family  health,  planning,  and  education. 
Community  participation  of  women  will  further  increase  their  confidence  and  strengthen  civil 
society by recognizing women’s role. Exposure of men and women to other parts of the country 
will help them understand the benefits of social change and contribute to a gradual change in 
attitude  toward  women’s  roles.  The  time-saving  household  devices  and  the  community-based 
social  infrastructure  are  aimed  at  reducing  women’s  time  spent  on  household  chores  and  will 
result  in  more  participation  in  community  initiatives.  The  biogas  plants  and  improved  cooking 
stoves  are  estimated  to  save  women  150  minutes  each  day  because  of  shorter  time  spent  in 
cooking  and  in  collecting  firewood.  The  time  saved,  used  for  either  leisure  or  productive

66. 
Project  will  have  an  immediate  effect  on  strengthening  the  DWD  and  WDO  to  increase  their

and  employment  generation  among  women,  and  raise  their  income  and  social  status.  The

community projects, and (ii) promote good governance through effective participation of women. 
 
67. 
The Project is unlikely to have any negative impact on the environment. All schemes will 
(i) be small scale and will neither adversely affect the natural resource base nor cause pollution, 
and (ii) undergo an environmental screening process. The Project will develop an environmental 
checklist  for  planning,  in  accordance  with  the  Government’s  and  ADB’s  Environmental 
Assessment Guidelines and Requirements. At all times during implementation, it will adhere to 
ADB policies and guidelines on the environment (Supplementary Appendix O). Land acquisition 
and resettlement are not expected to take place. The Government will ensure that all facilities to 
be constructed, extended, or upgraded under the Project will be located on land owned by the 
Government  and  no  resettlement  of  people,  including  squatters,  will  be  involved.  If  any 
involuntary  resettlement  or  land  acquisition  will  be  required,  the  Government  will  follow  ADB’s 
policy  on  involuntary  resettlement  and  develop  resettlement  plans  in  accordance  with  the 
framework in Supplementary Appendix P. 
 
B. 

Risks 

68. 
The  return  to  armed  conflict  and  the  current  political  instability  are  serious  risks  in 
successfully  implementing  the  Project.  However,  because  the  communities  consider  WDO 
activities as highly pro-poor, WDO staff was able to continue to operate throughout the conflict. 
This situation is expected to prevail during project implementation. In addition, specific conflict-
sensitive features have been incorporated in the project design.  
 
General risks associated with implementing projects in Nepal include late start-up, weak 
69. 
implementation capacity, and lack of locally elected officials at DDC and VDC level. These risks 
have  been  substantially  reduced  through  the  project  design  that  strongly  emphasizes 
organizational  capacity  building,  recruitment  of  key  staff  as  a  condition  for  loan  effectiveness, 
and  pre-project  hiring  of  consultants  to  facilitate  project  start-up.  In  addition,  the  CPMT  will 
develop 
transparent  contractual  arrangements,  specifying  roles  and  responsibilities  of 
government  institutions  and  SPs  before  the  Project  starts.  The  present  lack  of  locally  elected 
officials  at  DDC  and  VDC  levels  weakens  the  participatory  decentralized  approach  and  may 
adversely affect project implementation until elections are held. 
 
70. 
A  specific  risk  associated  with  the  Project  is  that  the  executing  agency  may  not  have 
adequate  capacity  to  effectively  coordinate  activities.  To  address  this  risk,  the  Project 
emphasizes  strengthening  of  DWD  and  WDO  through  staffing  with  relevant  expertise 
accompanied by staff orientation and training. The Project will also provide training and support 
to  the  DDCs  and  district-based  NGOs  to  build  their  capacity.  Gender  sensitization  will 

 19 

encourage support agencies to be more responsive to women’s needs. Another specific risk is 
that  MFIs  may  not  be  responsive  as  envisaged  in  providing  loans  to  the  target  groups.  The 
Project  seeks  to  reduce  this  risk  by  investing  in  strengthening  the  linkages  between  MFIs, 
NGOs, WGs, and SCCs; and in building the capacity of the WGs to establish a track record of 
sound management to make them attractive clients for MFIs. The final risk is that the targeted 
poor rural women are constrained in participating in project activities due to lack of time, energy, 
and  self-confidence.  To  address  this  problem,  the  Project  provides  support  for  activities  to 
reduce  time-consuming  tasks  for  women,  and  to  enhance  their  self-confidence  through  group 
mobilization.  The  demonstration  effect  of  women  leaders  participating  in  the  Project  will 
motivate the poorest women.

IMPACT OF THE MAOIST INSURGENCY 

 
1. 
Background. On 29 January 2003, representatives of the Government of Nepal and the 
leaders of the Maoist insurgency announced a ceasefire to begin negotiations toward a peaceful 
resolution  of  the  conflict  in  Nepal.  Unfortunately,  on  27  August  2003  the  breakdown  of  the 
cease-fire was announced. While the intensity of insurgency remains higher in Midwestern and 
Far  Western  regions,  all  regions  are  now  affected  by  conflict  and  insecurity.  The  conflict  has 
claimed  thousands  of  lives  over  the  past  7  years  and  has  affected  the  most  remote  and  least 
developed  districts.  It  has  affected  agriculture  and  people’s  livelihood;  separated  farm  owners 
from their lands; laid off workers from their jobs; and has disturbed the employment opportunity 
in  the  rural  areas,  thus  intensifying  exodus  of  villagers  to  the  cities  and  to  other  countries. 
Women,  children,  and  the  aged  have  been  more  severely  affected  because  all  of  them  feel 
insecure  and  defenseless  in  the  absence  of  the  men  in  the  family.  Women  have  also  been 
burdened by extra work and responsibility, lack of funds, and a continuous fear for their safety 
and  that  of  their  family.  The  number  of  women  employed  in  agriculture  decreased  during  the 
conflict  period,  with  a  most  negative  impact  on  employment  in  Far  Western,  Midwestern,  and 
Central  regions.  While  the  situation  certainly  led  to  the  global  decrease  of  income,  some 
tenants,  home  keepers,  and  workers  took  advantage  of  the  situation  by  cultivating  land  and 
keeping the full production. 
 
Displaced  People.  About  402,100  persons  are  displaced  in  the  53  most  affected 
2. 
districts,  distressing  a  population  of  about  2,412  million.1  The  main  reasons  for  displacement 
are: death threats (43%), request for unreasonable donations (31%), looting and burning (5%), 
land taken by Maoists (3%). Other residents have moved because relatives are employed in the 
security  force  or  police,  have  the  wrong  political  affiliation,  or  are  peace  activists.  Living 
conditions and food security have deteriorated, but not at an alarming stage due to the favorable

farmers and agricultural workers is in Far Western and Midwestern regions. Several displaced 
people have migrated to India and secondary towns to look for job opportunities, and additional 
remittances came from outside during the conflict period. These coping mechanisms may have 
in a way reduced the vulnerability of some but not all households.

Women’s household and farm-related work burden has increased dramatically because 
many male members have left the villages (either they are migrated or displaced). Women must

early to say to what extent the positive changes are sustainable because they have taken place

1.

credit  for  agricultural  production,  microenterprises  (MEs),  and  small  businesses  to  10,500, 
3,000, and 300 women, respectively. The remaining women beneficiaries were expected to rely 
on  their  own  savings  or  to  obtain  credit  from  other  sources.  The  Department  of  Women

THE DEPARTMENT OF WOMEN DEVELOPMENT (DWD)  
 

1. 
Ministry  of  Women,  Children,  and  Social  Welfare.  The  Ministry  of  Women,  Children 
and  Social  Welfare  (MOWCSW)  has  the  mandate  to  mainstream  women’s  empowerment  and 
gender  into  all  government  programs  and  policies.  Programs  for  empowerment  and  gender 
mainstreaming  are  executed  by  the  Department  of  Women  Development  (DWD),  which  was 
originally  formed  as  the  Women  Development  Office  (WDO)  of  the  Ministry  of  Local 
Development to implement the Production Credit for Rural Women project in 1982. The section 
became  a  department  (the  Women  Development  Department)  in  1991,  and  then  was 
transferred to the MOWCSW as DWD in 2000. 
 
2. 
Department of Women Development. DWD has the mandate to improve the quality of 
life, increase the socioeconomic status of women, and bring gender equity in Nepalese society. 
It  focuses  specifically  on  the  income  poor  and  disadvantaged  women  and  their  households. 
DWD  implements  the  Women  Development  Program  (WDP),  comprising  three  principal 
projects:  (i)  Production  Credit  for  Rural  Women,  (ii)  Micro  Credit  Project  for  Women  (MCPW); 
and,  (iii)  Women’s  Awareness  and  Income  Generation  Program  (‘Jagriti’).  DWD  coordinates 
programming with government, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), financial institutions, and 
funding agencies. 
 
DWD has a central administrative unit responsible for overall planning, implementation, 
3. 
monitoring and evaluation of WDP  in Kathmandu. DWD implements through 75 district offices 
(referred to as WDO), one in each district of Nepal) and 96 unit suboffices. The director general 
heads  the  department  and  takes  overall  responsibility  for  program  implementation.  He  is 
supported by directors, officers, and assistants. The program is implemented at the district level, 
with a high degree of decentralized management authority and operational autonomy, through 
the  WDO  headed  by  the  women  development  officers  (WDOfs),  assisted  by  a  supervisor,  an 
accountant  and  several  women  development  assistants  (WDAs).  Currently  involved  with  the 
WDD is a staff of 973. All WDOfs and WDAs are female staff. Within the Nepalese bureaucracy, 
DWD has the largest number of female staff working at the grassroots level. 
 
DWD  staff  are  directly  involved  in  group  formation,1  training,  community  development, 
4. 
and institutional development components of the WDP. DWD, during two decades of experience 
implementing projects to empower women in rural Nepal, has built a national infrastructure and 
network  that  reaches  every  district  of  Nepal.  DWD  staff  are  noted  for  their  dedication  and 
commitment  to  development  principles  and  the  department’s  work.  At  the  district  level,  WDO 
generally enjoys strong support of the line agencies, NGOs, and the community at large. 
 
5. 
The  principal  and  most  negative  factor  affecting  DWD  is  financial  constraints.  In  2001, 
the  development  budget  of  DWD  was  cut  by  more  than  80%,  leaving  very  limited  funds  for 
programs and only sufficient resources to maintain the administrative and staff structure. There 
have  been  further  budget  cuts  every  fiscal  year,  as  part  of  the  overall  Government  budget 
reductions arising from the budgetary deficit. This has been demotivational and demoralizing for 
all  DWD  staff,  in  addition  to  the  fact  that  all  WDO  positions  are  temporary  and  on  6-month 
contracts. Active programs in DWD are limited to those districts with ongoing externally funded 
projects.  Consequently,  there  is  a  large  reserve  of  underutilized  human  resource  capacity  in 
DWD.  Remobilizing  and  remotivating  department  staff  constitute  a  human  resource 
management challenge.

The human development index (HDI) ranks Nepal 143 out of 175 countries, lower than all Asian countries 
but  Pakistan.2  While  the  overall  HDI  for  Nepal  is  low,  the  index  disaggregated  by  regions  highlights  the 
inequity  of  development  across  Nepal.  Marked  disparities  occur  between  urban  and  rural  areas  and 
between ecological zones. Head count index, poverty gap index and squared poverty gap index, confirm 
these disparities. The head count index, for example, places below the poverty line 56% of the population 
in the mountains, 41% in the hills, and 42% in the terai; whereas 23% in the urban areas and 44% in the 
rural areas of the population live below the poverty line.3 Not only spatial disparities in incomes and human 
development  are  important  elements  of  poverty  in  Nepal;  gender,  ethnicity  and  caste-related  differentials 
add to the complexity, and exacerbate the intensity and depth of poverty.4

between men and women in the HDI shows similar regional differences, but an overall positive trend. The

Social Stratification and Characteristics of Poverty  in the Western Cluster.9 Ethnic/caste diversity in 
the Western cluster is high, with 19 different castes/ethnic groups to be distinguished. Three ethnic/caste 
groups  generally  dominate,  with about 70%  of  the population:  most  often  they consist  of Chetri,  Brahmin 
and  one  other  dalit  group.  Diversity  of  other  ethic/castes  origins  is  limited.  The  settlement  pattern  is 
relatively  homogeneous,  with  single  ethnic/caste  groups  forming  clusters  within  a  ward.10  This  suggests 
social cohesion and long historical relationship between households and it seems favorable for community 
participation and social grouping. But strong historical relationships and remoteness are not conducive to 
attitudinal and behavioral changes and the reduction of discriminatory practices. In the Western cluster the 
vulnerable and poor population makes up 22% and 35% respectively, the medium group is 30%, and the 
well-off  group  is  13%.  In  the  last  30  years,  the  rural  population  has  embarked  in  a  diversified  livelihood 
system.  With  the  increased  population  density  over  resources,  farming  system  intensification  became 
mandatory.  Small  farm  size  and  high  land  fragmentation  within  families  of  landowners  do  not  encourage 
interesting commercial agriculture, and limit the local demand for seasonal   employment. Access network 
of limited and poor quality also constraints the mobility of people and access to district and regional markets. In the 
West, most of the rural communities have modified or diversified their sources of income by (i) migrating 
permanently to the terai or to towns; (ii) seeking seasonal employment in the terai, towns, and Punjab; or 
(iii) migrating overseas. These strategies released the pressure on land and in brought external income to 
sustain life in the area. Estimates indicate that incomes from migration represent between 40% and 60% of 
the total income, and more than 60% of the cash income. Migrating is not a coping mechanism anymore, 
but a permanent component of the livelihood system in western Nepal.

Social Stratification and Characteristics of Poverty in the Central Cluster. Ethnic/caste diversity in the 
Central cluster is very high, with 51 different caste/ethnic groups to be distinguished. There is a much wider 
mosaic  of  caste/ethnic  groups,  several  of  them  migrated  from  the  hills,  mountains,  and  India.  The  most 
important  groups  are  the  Yadav  (12.3%  of  the  population),  Muslim  (11%),  Thamang  (6.3%),  Brahmin-hill 
(4.5%),  and  Tharu  (3.7%).  Settlement  patterns  show  clusters  formed  of  nuclei  of  endemic  castes/ethnic 
groups, which were joined by other ethnic/caste groups in the last 40-50 years. The new groups came to 
find  land,  to  benefit  from  easy  communication  and  market,  or  more  recently  to  escape  the  Maoist 
insurgency from the hills and mountain areas. The new groups live closely together, and keep their social 
references,  traditional  livelihoods,  and  habitat  pattern.  However,  development  initiatives  modify  the  social 
and  economic  dynamics  of  the  communities  and  challenge  the  power  relations,  in  which  caste/ethnic 
issues are of primary importance. Social cohesion and participation in development efforts therefore cannot 
readily  be  assumed.  In  the  Central  cluster,  the  vulnerable  and  the  poor  comprise  31%  and  32%  of  the 
population, 28% are considered as medium, and 9% as well-off. 
 
In the terai districts, with large flat land of alluvial soil and excellent groundwater resources, the traditional 
rural  system  is  based  on  food  and  commercial  cropping,  and  livestock  husbandry.  Due  to  the  very  high 
population  density,  combined  with  small  farm  size  and  high  land  fragmentation,  food  subsistence  and 
commercial  agriculture  alone  are  not  sufficient  for  most  of  the  rural  households.  Rich  and  medium 
socioeconomic groups have turned to trade, business, out-migration, permanent paid job, agro-processing, 
and small or medium-scale commercial agriculture. Vulnerable and poor groups seek local employment in 
farming,  brick  making,  sand  collection,  construction,  low  paid  urban  services,  or  migrate  to  Punjab. 
Savings, if any, are invested in livestock, buy and sell business, or cottage industry.  because of the range 
of  altitude  and  the  variations  in  soil  types  in  the  central  and  northern  parts  of  the  hills,  cropping  systems 
greatly vary. While monsoon crops are usually for the household consumption, farmers with more than 1 ha 
of  irrigated  land  can  produce  off-season  commercial  crops,  including  high-value  crops,  and  several  fruit 
trees.

D.          Gender and Development  
 
The  thematic  of  the  Project  is  gender  and  development.  The  project  beneficiaries  are  poor  rural  women 
who have not benefited from past development programs. All activities focus on poor ethnic and low-caste 
groups  to  ensure  that  benefits  will  accrue  more  readily  to  these  disadvantaged  groups.  The  Project  will 
work,  not  only  with  existing  groups,  but  also  with  newly  formed  women’s  groups  to  allow  the  historically 
excluded women to participate in the Project.
